nodes.text: K-nearest neighbors (KNN) algorithm can be used to accurately predict the presence of heart disease from clinical and demographic data
KNN is an appropriate choice for this task because it is a non-parametric, instance-based classifier that uses distance (e.g., Euclidean) to infer labels from similar cases

The study uses a clinical dataset with features including age, sex, chest pain type, resting blood pressure, cholesterol, fasting blood sugar, rest ECG, max heart rate, exercise angina, oldpeak, slope, ca, thal and a binary target indicating heart disease
Preprocessing steps include feature selection, handling class imbalance via weighting strategies, feature scaling and repeated trials (repeats=3) with K set to 10 and averaging results
Model evaluation employed cross-validation and performance metrics including sensitivity, specificity, accuracy, confusion matrix and AUC-ROC
KNN uses Euclidean distance to find K nearest neighbors, then assigns class by majority vote; choice of K affects bias-variance (odd K to avoid ties; small K risks overfitting, large K risks noise)
Data visualization included histograms for numerical features and counts of affected individuals by sex, showing more male diagnoses associated with higher cholesterol and resting blood pressure
The experimental setup repeated the modeling three times, used K=10, averaged trials, and computed KNN classifier scores for different K values using the Euclidean distance formula
Confusion matrix results yield 38 true positives, 45 true negatives, 10 false positives, and 7 false negatives, producing an accuracy of 83%
Feature importance analysis was used to improve model interpretability and to identify key factors contributing to heart disease risk
Evaluation reports included accuracy and AUC-ROC values; authors state KNN achieved high accuracy and promising AUC-ROC in heart disease prediction
The study concludes that KNN is a promising, simple, and adaptable tool for heart disease prediction, aiding risk assessment, early detection and potentially improving clinical outcomes
KNN has known limitations: it is computationally expensive at classification time, sensitive to choice of K, and requires careful preprocessing (scaling, missing data handling)
